summary: The Becker lens reveals the host journey as a carefully sequenced armor-shedding cascade in which the host progressively exposes their private domestic space -- the innermost layer of their character armor -- to public scrutiny, stranger occupation, and economic valuation. Every phase demands the host lower defenses that protect their vital lie (the belief that their world is manageable and under control), and the platform must provide replacement defenses at every step. The seven UI elements synthesize this insight across all layers: a listing wizard progress card with armor-preservation auto-save, a proposal vetting card with stranger-trust signals positioned above terms, a pricing defaults card that delegates the terror of self-valuation to platform authority, a cleaning photo approval ritual card that provides sanctuary-restoration confirmation, a host dashboard urgency panel that externalizes the self-preservation instinct, a hosting legacy summary card that reframes vulnerability as an immortality project, and a pause/resume toggle that channels the retreat impulse into creative repression rather than destructive deletion. Together they form a coherent system where every layer of character armor that is shed is replaced by a platform-mediated defense, every stranger is made manageable through delegated credibility, and every ritual confirms that the host's hero system remains intact.

elements.name: Listing Wizard Progress Card with Armor-Preservation Auto-Save
elements.description: A dashboard card that shows the host's listing creation progress with a visual step tracker, auto-save confirmation, and one-click resume or pause controls. Becker's insight that the host 'doesn't bite the world off in one piece but in small manageable pieces, as a beaver does' informs the step-by-step design: each completed step is a piece of character armor the host has safely shed, and the progress tracker makes this investment visible. The auto-save indicator ('Saved just now') is the platform whispering 'I have your work' -- delegated power that allows the host to disengage without losing character work. Pause is the first action in the menu, more prominent than any destructive option, channeling the retreat impulse into creative repression rather than listing destruction.

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 480px. Top row: listing name + auto-save indicator. Encouragement line below. Progress bar. Step checklist with status icons. Bottom: Resume CTA + Pause text link.

color_usage.current_step_badge: #c17a28 on #fef3e2 -- amber for the step needing attention

copy_spec.encourage: Two more steps to go live. Your progress is saved.
dont: Never say 'Your listing is only X% complete' -- frame progress positively
Never use aspirational step titles ('Share your story', 'Set your value') -- these pierce the vital lie by making the existential weight explicit
Never use questions as field labels ('What makes your space special?') -- questions invite self-reflection that activates fear of self-knowledge

elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts abandon the listing wizard at the impasse-layer steps (photos, house rules) because the existential weight of self-exposure becomes conscious. This card fragments the exposure into beaver-sized pieces with visible, preserved progress, ensuring no character work is ever lost and the retreat to pause is always frictionless.

elements.name: Proposal Vetting Card with Stranger-Trust Signals
elements.description: A proposal review card that resolves the host's stranger-terror by placing guest trust signals (verification badge, review rating, completed stays, stated purpose) above proposal terms (dates, duration, price). Becker's insight that the stranger represents 'billions of individual organismic appetites' informs the trust-first architecture: the host's instinctual threat assessment must be resolved before rational term evaluation can begin. The verification badge is the platform-as-superego made visible -- communicating 'we have vetted this person; you are not forsaken.' The counter-offer button provides temporal control over vulnerability without rejecting the person. The three-button action bar uses graduated visual weight: Accept (filled purple, maximum prominence), Counter (outlined, medium), Decline (text-only, minimum) -- nudging toward the marketplace-sustaining action while preserving the host's sense of choice.

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 520px. Three zones: Trust Zone (top, tinted background with guest identity), Terms Zone (middle, white, structured grid), Action Zone (bottom, three graduated buttons).

copy_spec.message: Hi! I'm a product designer working a contract in Williamsburg. I keep a tidy space and work mostly from co-working spaces during the day. Looking forward to connecting.
dont: Never use excitement ('You have a new match!', 'Someone wants your space!') -- excitement amplifies anxiety
Never show a countdown timer on proposal response -- time pressure forces a decision before character defenses have processed the stranger
Never show 'Also applied to X other listings' -- this signals the stranger's appetites are diffuse and uncontrollable

elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts freeze or reflexively decline proposals when the stranger's credibility is not immediately visible. This card places the guest's verification badge, review rating, and stay history above the fold -- making trust the first thing the host processes and converting the terrifying stranger into a manageable, vetted person.

elements.name: Pricing Defaults Card with Delegated Confidence
elements.description: A pricing card that presents the platform's recommended price as a confident, pre-decided number -- not an open question. Becker's insight that people 'always rely on something that transcends us, some system of ideas and powers in which we are embedded' informs the visual hierarchy: the recommended price is a 36px hero number in DM Sans that dominates the card, communicating that the platform has already decided. The trust line ('Based on 12 similar rooms in Williamsburg') provides the host with an external authority to lean on. The guaranteed income projection in purple anchors the price to the host's primary anxiety buffer: predictable revenue. The 'Accept this price' button is full-width and prominent; the 'Adjust' link is below and subdued. The entire composition says: here is your price (certainty), here is what it means for you (security), you can change it if you must (agency).

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 440px, centered. Hero price at top. Trust line below. Guaranteed income in purple. Market range bar. Full-width Accept button. Subdued Adjust link.

copy_spec.label: We recommend
copy_spec.trust_line: Based on 12 similar rooms in Williamsburg
dont: Never present an empty price field -- an empty field is an existential void the host cannot fill without anxiety
Never say 'Set your own price' -- this forces autonomous self-determination that the host's character defenses are designed to avoid
Never show the platform's fee percentage before the host accepts the gross price -- fee revelation during self-valuation amplifies betrayal anxiety

elements.problem_it_solves: Setting a price forces the host to assign monetary value to something psychologically priceless -- their home. This card eliminates the existential void of an empty price field by presenting the platform's recommendation as a confident, pre-decided figure. The host accepts by embedding in the platform's authority, not by generating courage from their own center.

elements.name: Cleaning Photo Approval Ritual Card
elements.description: A dashboard card that surfaces cleaning photo verification as a ritual moment -- the host confirming their sanctuary survived stranger-contact and was restored. Becker's insight that 'self-preservation implies an effort against some force of disintegration' informs the card design: the photos are large (the host must see their space), the 'Approve: Space Restored' button uses the word 'Restored' (acknowledging something was at risk), and the confirmation state (purple checkmark overlay, 'Space verified' text) provides visual proof that can persist on the dashboard for 48 hours. The card moves from the urgency stack (amber border = needs attention) to a confirmed state (purple border = verified safe), enacting the psychological transition from vigilance to relief.

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 520px. Header: guest name + date. 2x2 photo grid. Action buttons below. Confirmed state overlay.

dont: Never add captions to individual photos -- the photos speak for themselves
Never auto-approve cleaning photos -- the host's explicit confirmation is the ritual seal
Never say 'Looks good!' -- casual language undermines the ritual significance

elements.problem_it_solves: During active lease, the host lives with chronic anxiety that their space may be damaged or disrespected by the stranger. The cleaning photo ritual provides a structured, conclusive outlet for this self-preservation instinct -- the host actively verifies their sanctuary is intact, and the confirmed state persists as visual proof that repression can re-engage.

elements.name: Host Dashboard Urgency Panel
elements.description: The top section of the host dashboard that surfaces action-required items as the host's externalized self-preservation instinct. Becker writes that 'such constant expenditure of psychological energy on the business of preserving life would be impossible if the fear of death were not as constant.' This panel converts the diffuse anxiety of stranger-in-home into discrete, actionable items. Each urgency card uses a left-border accent system: amber (#c17a28) for items needing attention, purple (rgb(109,49,194)) for informational items already handled. The panel heading 'Needs your attention' and the empty state 'All caught up' are the two poles of the host's dashboard experience -- threat-scanning and equanimity. The panel never rearranges between visits, providing the civilizational order that Becker identifies as a precondition for equanimity.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width panel, max-width 640px. Heading + vertical stack of up to 5 action cards. Each card: icon + description + deadline + action button.

copy_spec.heading: Needs your attention

example_items.desc: Review cleaning photos from Jordan Rivera
Date change request from Marcus Chen

copy_spec.empty_state: All caught up. Nothing needs your attention right now.
dont: Never place promotional banners above the urgency panel -- the host's vigilant state reads non-urgent content as the platform ignoring their needs
Never use red badges for routine attention items -- only for genuine sanctuary-threat events (overdue cleaning photos, missed payment)
Never rearrange the panel's position on the page between visits -- positional consistency is character armor

elements.problem_it_solves: Without a centralized urgency panel, the host's self-preservation instinct has no structured outlet. Anxiety becomes diffuse -- manifesting as excessive messaging, micromanagement, or premature lease termination. This panel converts chronic background anxiety into discrete, resolvable items that the host can process and clear, restoring the vital lie that everything is under control.

elements.name: Hosting Legacy Summary Card
elements.description: A celebratory summary card presented at lease completion that reframes the hosting experience as an immortality project -- a contribution that transcends the individual transaction. Becker writes that 'the deepest need is to be free of the anxiety of death and annihilation; but it is life itself which awakens it, and so we must shrink from being fully alive.' This card provides the narcissistic supply needed to sustain the host's expanded hero system. The income hero number (36px DM Sans) declares the material value of the host's vulnerability. The three impact metrics (guests welcomed, months provided, average rating) provide evidence of meaningful contribution. Review snippets are voices of former strangers confirming the encounter was positive. The re-list CTA appears after validation -- the host decides from a position of affirmed strength, not unresolved anxiety. Pause is positioned as an equally dignified option: 'Take a break.'

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 520px. Purple-tinted canvas background. Hero income. Three-column metrics. Review snippet cards. Re-list CTA + Pause link.

elements.problem_it_solves: At lease end, the host faces the existential question: was it worth it? Without a structured legacy narrative, the raw memory of hosting (anxiety, stranger-intrusion, control negotiations) overwhelms the positive outcomes. This card provides evidence that the vulnerability produced meaningful contribution -- income earned, guests served, positive validation -- giving the host the narcissistic supply needed to rebuild the vital lie around continued hosting.

elements.name: Pause / Resume Listing Toggle
elements.description: A listing card state toggle that allows the host to pause (retreat from exposure) or resume (re-engage) with a single tap and zero friction. Becker's insight that 'repression is not simply a negative force opposing life energies; it lives on life energies and uses them creatively' informs the design: pause IS creative repression -- channeling the retreat impulse into a productive holding state rather than destructive deletion. The paused state desaturates the listing card and shows a 'Paused' badge, making the retreat visible without making it punitive. Resume restores full color and live status. No confirmation modal on pause -- the host's boundary is respected without interrogation. No reason-collection form -- forcing the host to articulate their retreat breaks the repressive defense that makes pause psychologically viable. This card shows both the live and paused states side by side for comparison.

visual_spec.layout: Two cards side by side (live vs. paused) at max-width 260px each. Each card: listing photo placeholder, title, status badge, action menu.

dont: Never show an 'Are you sure?' modal on pause -- the host's boundary must be respected without interrogation
Never require the host to explain why they are pausing -- forced articulation breaks the repressive defense
Never send 'We miss you' re-engagement emails within the first 45 days -- respect the retreat
